caption: Table 2: Real robot results. Our method MCR performs best in all tasks. Each method is fairly assessed over 10 trials on each task.
description: Table 2 presents the results of three real-world robotic manipulation tasks, showing that the proposed MCR method outperforms other baselines.

caption: Table 4: Key design choices of MCR.
description: The table shows the ablation study of MCR, evaluating the impact of each training objective and design choice on the success rate.

caption: Table 5: Computation efficiency. Training computation requirements across methods.
description: The table shows the training time of different methods for pre-training visual representations for robotic manipulation, comparing GPU types and training duration.

caption: Table 8: Grad-CAM of all tasks
description: Table 8 presents Grad-CAM visualizations for each task, comparing the performance of various methods in highlighting manipulation-centric regions.

caption: Table 6: Hyperparameters for MCR pre-training.
description: This table lists the hyperparameters used for pre-training the Manipulation Centric Representation (MCR) model.

caption: Table 7: Main results on 20 simulation tasks. Results for each task are provided in this table. A summary across domains is shown in Figure 7.
description: The table presents the success rates of different methods (MCR, LfS, MVP, VC1, R3M, HRP, R3M-DROID) across 20 robotic manipulation tasks from four simulation environments.
